headline.main: MONDALE-GLENN CHOICE SPLITS UNIONISTS IN POLL

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: AMERICAN FEDERATION OF LABOR-CONGRESS OF INDUSTRIAL ORGANIZATIONS

results.snippet: Rank-and-file union members are about evenly divided in their support for Walter F. Mondale and John Glenn, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.   Leaders of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations...
results.lead_paragraph: Rank-and-file union members are about evenly divided in their support for Walter F. Mondale and John Glenn, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. Leaders of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations recommended yesterday that the federation endorse Mr. Mondale as the Democratic nominee for President in 1984. But the poll suggested that the endorsement would not suddenly swing most of the membership behind Mr. Mondale. Mr. Mondale, the former Vice President, was favored by 34 percent of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. members interviewed in the poll, and 29 percent said they favored Mr. Glenn, the Senator from Ohio. The five percentage point difference was within the poll's margin of sampling error.

headline.main: WILL NASA'S PET PROJECT FIZZLE OR FLY?

results.snippet: As the National Aeronautics and Space Administration marks its 25th anniversary this weekend, a fierce battle is being waged in Washington over the agency's proposed mandate for the next 25 years - the development of a huge orbiting space station...
results.lead_paragraph: As the National Aeronautics and Space Administration marks its 25th anniversary this weekend, a fierce battle is being waged in Washington over the agency's proposed mandate for the next 25 years - the development of a huge orbiting space station with a full-time crew. Until a few weeks ago, it looked as if NASA had won. The agency had enlisted strong allies in Congress, the Commerce Department and the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. It had found supporters among White House science and political advisers. Aerospace industry leaders who met with President Reagan came away believing he favored authorizing the project.

headline.main: ANTIWAR MARCHES ARE HELD IN SOVIET

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT

results.snippet: Muscovites by the tens of thousands converged in well-drilled columns today on six rally sites for what was officially termed an antiwar demonstration.   Demonstrations are generally not permitted unless sanctioned by the authorities. Placards...

byline.original: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Muscovites by the tens of thousands converged in well-drilled columns today on six rally sites for what was officially termed an antiwar demonstration. Demonstrations are generally not permitted unless sanctioned by the authorities. Placards carried by the marchers and slogans spelled out by combining big letter cards hailed the initiatives of the Soviet Government and assailed the foreign policy of the Reagan Administration. The timing of the rallies, two days after Yuri V. Andropov had issued a strong indictment of President Reagan's policies, seemed to indicate the start a Soviet publicity campaign aimed at preventing the deployment of American medium-range missiles in Western Europe starting in December.

results.snippet: The Unanswered Question    The PBS series called ''Why in the   World'' is a discussion between a panel of high school students and a national figure. Yesterday as the current season's first show was being taped at WNET, on West 58th Street, the...

byline.original: By David Bird and Maurice Carroll

results.lead_paragraph: The Unanswered Question The PBS series called ''Why in the World'' is a discussion between a panel of high school students and a national figure. Yesterday as the current season's first show was being taped at WNET, on West 58th Street, the students learned something about the problems of television. Part way through the taping, there were technical difficulties and the discussion had to be stopped and started again as corrected pieces were inserted in the tape.

headline.kicker: FORUM ON ISSUES: GLENN'S RIGHT STUFF

results.snippet: In politics, as in sports and gambling, it is sometimes as important to be lucky as to be good. And Senator John Glenn's remarkable run of political luck continued Thursday night when the seven Democratic Presidential candidates made their first...
results.lead_paragraph: In politics, as in sports and gambling, it is sometimes as important to be lucky as to be good. And Senator John Glenn's remarkable run of political luck continued Thursday night when the seven Democratic Presidential candidates made their first joint appearance. At the issues forum conducted by the New York Democratic State Committee, Mr. Glenn seemed to wander when he was asked complicated questions on immigration and economic policy. But then James David Barber, author and political scientist, challenged the Senator's political credentials by likening his space flight in 1962, when he became the first American in orbit, to such publicity stunts as Evel Knievel's attempt in 1974 to vault the Snake River canyon on a rocket-propelled motorcycle.

headline.main: ON HOLIDAY, THE GAME IS AFOOT

results.snippet: Taking to the road means planning ahead. Weather is everything to the walker. Although the temperate climate of Western Europe makes it possible to walk anywhere at almost any time of year, spring and autumn may be best for the walks described...

byline.original: By Adam Nicolson, Arthur Howcroft and Jonathan Hurdle; Arthur Howcroft, with Richard Sale, is the author off ''A Walker's Guide to Europe'' (Wildwood, London); Jonathan Hurdle is the author of ''The Alpine Pass Route'' (Dark Peak Ltd., Sheffield, England

results.lead_paragraph: Taking to the road means planning ahead. Weather is everything to the walker. Although the temperate climate of Western Europe makes it possible to walk anywhere at almost any time of year, spring and autumn may be best for the walks described below, especially in some areas of France, where the summer is hot and dry. Spring arrives later in the northern climes and is delayed by altitude. The suggested itineraries cover histsoric and scenic regions of Britain, France, Germany and Switzerland. The degree of skill and amount of time involved vary from a day or two to a week. Some of the walks are gentle rambles, others are demanding treks over sometimes tricky terrain. Suggestions for guidebooks and accommodations follow each walk. BRITAIN 1. Crossing From Coast to Coast 190 miles/304 kilometers from Robin Hood's Bay in Yorkshire to Saint Bee's in Cumbria. Alternating moorland and easy field paths, one or two serious climbs at the western end.

results.lead_paragraph: * California Federal Savings and Loan Association has named James B. Jacobson executive vice president in charge of non-real estate subsidiaries, and Charles W. Woodford chairman and chief executive officer of its Trust Services of America Inc. subsidiary. * Clorox Co., Oakland, Calif., has named Edward A. Cutter vice president-general counsel and secretary. * Corning Glass Works has elected to its board Vernon E. Jordan Jr., a partner in the Washington law firm of Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld and former president of the National Urban League.

headline.main: GLENN URGES HOLDING UP MISSILE DEPLOYMENT

results.snippet: Senator John Glenn of Ohio urged President Reagan today to call a halt to the planned deployment of cruise missiles in Europe to show a sign of ''good faith'' toward the Soviet Union.   Senator Glenn, who is seeking the Democratic Presidential...
results.lead_paragraph: Senator John Glenn of Ohio urged President Reagan today to call a halt to the planned deployment of cruise missiles in Europe to show a sign of ''good faith'' toward the Soviet Union. Senator Glenn, who is seeking the Democratic Presidential nomination, also called for negotiations on a mutual ban on the installation of the ground- based missiles, which are winged, jet-powered bombs, but conceded that he did not know if Moscow would agree. ''A cruise missile race would be a major setback for the cause of arms control,'' the Senator said, ''and I believe we must make one last-ditch effort to keep it from occurring.

headline.main: DEMOCRATS OPEN AD BATTLE IN NOMINATION DRIVE

results.snippet: In New Hampshire towns such as Keene, Laconia and Lebanon, radio listeners are being invited by Senator Gary Hart of Colorado to join his ''campaign for a new America.''    In Iowa, voters are being offered 10-minute cassettes for their automobile...
results.lead_paragraph: In New Hampshire towns such as Keene, Laconia and Lebanon, radio listeners are being invited by Senator Gary Hart of Colorado to join his ''campaign for a new America.'' In Iowa, voters are being offered 10-minute cassettes for their automobile tape players so that, as they drive along, they can hear former Gov. Reubin Askew explain why he is ''the different Democrat.'' This coming Saturday night, on the eve of the premiere of the movie ''The Right Stuff,'' television viewers watching the CBS network are to see a five-minute commercial designed to convince them that Senator John Glenn of Ohio is more than an astronaut. For the Democratic Presidential candidates, the electronic media battle has begun.

results.snippet: Unusual and Unlikely   At the ''issues lunch'' President Reagan holds to hear the views of his staff members, several people were startled this week to hear some unusual advice from William P. Clark, the outgoing national security adviser, and some...

byline.original: By James F. Clarity and Warren Weaver Jr

results.lead_paragraph: Unusual and Unlikely At the ''issues lunch'' President Reagan holds to hear the views of his staff members, several people were startled this week to hear some unusual advice from William P. Clark, the outgoing national security adviser, and some equally unlikely countercomment by James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff. In the last year, Mr. Clark, who was nominated yesterday by the President as Secretary of the Interior, has opposed colleagues on the White House staff who have counseled compromise on issues such as the MX missile, the military budget and Central America; Mr. Baker was often the one advocating compromise. But on Tuesday in the Cabinet Room, Mr. Clark warned colleagues not to allow the coming Presidential campaign to undo the bipartisan compromises he and Mr. Baker had helped work out recently on some of these issues. According to those present, Mr. Clark said it was more important to preserve bipartisan support for the President's initiatives on arms control and Central America than to attack Democrats who opposed them. Mr. Baker reportedly responded by asserting graciously that foreign policy, Mr. Clark's province at the time, was proving to be a stronger asset for Mr. Reagan politically than anyone had previously realized. An official said Mr. Reagan did not respond to this exchange.

results.snippet: NewsAnalysis    WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 - For two weeks there has been an escalating exchange of charges between former Vice President Walter F. Mondale and Senator John Glenn of Ohio. On its surface, this has been a debate over Democratic Party...
results.lead_paragraph: NewsAnalysis WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 - For two weeks there has been an escalating exchange of charges between former Vice President Walter F. Mondale and Senator John Glenn of Ohio. On its surface, this has been a debate over Democratic Party credentials, over issues such as arms control and over legislative matters such as Mr. Glenn's vote for President Reagan's income tax reduction. But, on a deeper level, what is going on is a contest to see whether it is Mr. Glenn himself or Mr. Mondale who gets to define the political personality that Mr. Glenn projects to the voters in next year's Presidential campaign. Strategists on both sides believe it is this definitional struggle that could be decisive in the race for the Democratic nomination.

results.snippet: Watching the Democratic candidates at the recent New York Presidential forum, I found myself thinking, ''John Glenn really does look like Eisenhower.'' At that moment, my daughter, almost 16, asked, ''Is John Glenn the one who looks like Johnny...
results.lead_paragraph: Watching the Democratic candidates at the recent New York Presidential forum, I found myself thinking, ''John Glenn really does look like Eisenhower.'' At that moment, my daughter, almost 16, asked, ''Is John Glenn the one who looks like Johnny Carson?'' Johnny Carson? She had a point. The silver-domed star of the ''Tonight'' show does resemble the silver-domed former astronaut. But it was not a comparison I would ever have thought to make. To my middle-aged sensibility, the image of the television comedian will forever be impish and restless, that of the Ohio Senator solid and deliberate.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT

results.snippet: The seven Democratic candidates for President clashed here tonight in a debate over arms control as Senator John Glenn and former Vice President Walter F. Mondale taunted each other for positions they had taken in the past.   The hourlong debate,...

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The seven Democratic candidates for President clashed here tonight in a debate over arms control as Senator John Glenn and former Vice President Walter F. Mondale taunted each other for positions they had taken in the past. The hourlong debate, at Harvard University, produced no clear winners in what was, for the most part, a well-mannered, intellectually challenging exchange over one of the most important, divisive issues in the contest for the Democratic nomination. But Senator Alan Cranston of California impressed many in the audience of arms control advocates with his passionate, single-minded emphasis on the dangers of nuclear war. ''Abraham Lincoln was criticized in 1860 for being a single-issue candidate when he concentrated on preserving the Union and checking slavery,'' Mr. Cranston said. ''What is wrong with being labeled a single-issue candidate if your goal is ending an arms race that threatens our very survival, that undermines our economy and wrecks our capacity to deal with all other issues?''

headline.main: CONTROVERSY OVER JANE FONDA COSTS NASA OFFICIAL HIS POST

results.snippet: The space agency's director of public affairs is leaving his post amid controversy over the attention given to Jane Fonda, the actress and political activist, who was an invited guest at a space shuttle launching last June. Both White House and...
results.lead_paragraph: The space agency's director of public affairs is leaving his post amid controversy over the attention given to Jane Fonda, the actress and political activist, who was an invited guest at a space shuttle launching last June. Both White House and space officials confirmed yesterday that they had been upset by the controversy and by remarks made by the director that were considered favorable to Miss Fonda. Brian Duff, the director, said in a telephone interview that he had asked for a reassignment. He said he had not been asked to resign but acknowledged that he had lost ''rapport'' with senior managers at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in Washington and that criticism of his statements about Miss Fonda had ''contributed'' to his problems and his decision to quit.

headline.main: 'THE RIGHT STUFF': FROM SPACE TO THE SCREEN

results.snippet: There were heroes in those days, some 25 years ago, when Americans still seemed to feel sure enough of themselves to believe in heroes. Like the dragon-slayers of myth, a few men went forth to meet the demons in the sky and do battle in behalf of...
results.lead_paragraph: There were heroes in those days, some 25 years ago, when Americans still seemed to feel sure enough of themselves to believe in heroes. Like the dragon-slayers of myth, a few men went forth to meet the demons in the sky and do battle in behalf of all lesser mortals. They were acclaimed heroes because they seemed to embody the qualities most esteemed by Americans, rare qualities that were thought to define the best in the national character. These few men, test pilots and the early astronauts, were plain-spoken, rugged individualists who made no apologies for devotion to duty and country. They mastered difficult skills and, as much as anyone could, were masters of their fate. They were incredibly good at what they did and knew it, but had the grace not to flaunt it. And what they did, with risk-all bravery, brought tears of wonder and pride to the eyes of those who beheld their daring and accomplishment. The new movie, ''The Right Stuff,'' opening Friday at local theaters, is a nostalgic scrapbook of this past and an unabashed celebration of the men who are characterized as ''the last true American heroes.'' It is an old-fashioned adventure story.

results.snippet: Glenn on Celluloid And in Real Life   ''The Right Stuff'' got a New York   showing the other night, and Democrats who support John Glenn for President came out smiling.   There were two spurts of applause during the movie, which is about the...

byline.original: By David Bird and Maurice Carroll

results.lead_paragraph: Glenn on Celluloid And in Real Life ''The Right Stuff'' got a New York showing the other night, and Democrats who support John Glenn for President came out smiling. There were two spurts of applause during the movie, which is about the Mercury astronauts.

results.snippet: The Red Line    There were blinking red lights   and possibly some red faces,   but apparently no Red agents involved. It happened the other night at the Langley, Va., headquarters of the Central Intelligence Agency, which is almost impenetrable.  ...

byline.original: By James F. Clarity and Warren Weaver Jr

results.lead_paragraph: The Red Line There were blinking red lights and possibly some red faces, but apparently no Red agents involved. It happened the other night at the Langley, Va., headquarters of the Central Intelligence Agency, which is almost impenetrable. An eyewitness to the event agreed to debriefing on condition that his identity and commuting schedule remain secret. Here is his uncoded, unclassified dispatch: The 5-W bus, which runs between downtown Washington and the Virginia suburbs, does not stop at the headquarters of the Central Intelligence Agency. Only the 5-K bus has permission to enter the heavily guarded complex and, even then, only passengers who flash special identity cards are allowed to debark. There are men with guns to enforce this rule.

results.snippet: ''THE RIGHT STUFF,'' Philip Kaufman's rousing, funny screen adaptation of Tom Wolfe's book about Project Mercury and America's first astronauts, is probably the brightest and the best rookie/cadet movie ever made, though the rookies and cadets are...
results.lead_paragraph: ''THE RIGHT STUFF,'' Philip Kaufman's rousing, funny screen adaptation of Tom Wolfe's book about Project Mercury and America's first astronauts, is probably the brightest and the best rookie/cadet movie ever made, though the rookies and cadets are seasoned pilots and officers. The film almost makes one glad to be alive in spite of famines, wars and even ''the greenhouse effect,'' which, if the Environmental Protection Agency is correct, means that the entire earth is inside its own space capsule that's rapidly overheating. ''The Right Stuff'' is full of short-term pleasures that yield to doubts only after the film is over. Although the film, which opens today at the Beekman and other theaters, focuses mainly on the care, feeding, training and exploitation of the astronauts, its most commanding figure is not an astronaut but a great test pilot, Chuck Yeager, who exemplifies everything represented by the title. Mr. Yeager, who in 1947 became the first man in the world to break the sound barrier, was not a member of Project Mercury but his story, in the film as in the book, more or less frames those of the astronauts. Systematically testing himself as well as his planes or, in the jargon of the space trade, ''pushing the outside of the envelope,'' Mr. Yeager was the man against whom any pilot who thought he had the right stuff measured himself.

headline.main: TWO DEMOCRATS IN SEARCH OF A SOUTHERN STRATEGY

results.snippet: The political setting here last week was one in which former Vice President Walter F. Mondale is at his best. The hand-picked audience of 200 ardent Democrats, most of them New South progressives who had been associated with former President...
results.lead_paragraph: The political setting here last week was one in which former Vice President Walter F. Mondale is at his best. The hand-picked audience of 200 ardent Democrats, most of them New South progressives who had been associated with former President Carter, represented the Southern Democratic Party's loftiest instincts if not its usual voting patterns. The discussion, by a panel that included Mr. Mondale, Mr. Carter, and former Secretary of State Dean Rusk, was high-toned and enlightened. As in other such gatherings of his party's elite, Mr. Mondale demonstrated the easy wit, detailed knowledge and political acumen that often seem lacking in the public performances of his nearest competitor in the opinion polls, Senator John Glenn. All the same, a worrisome question hovered at the edge of Herbert Mabry's mind even as he nodded in agreement with Mr. Mondale's words. Mr. Mabry, the seasoned president of the Georgia American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations, is fully committed to Mr. Mondale and zealous about producing the labor vote to defeat Mr. Glenn. He has also seen a lot of campaigns. That is why he turned to a companion and gave words to his question: ''Can he win?''

results.snippet: '76 Glenn Speech Flap    Senator John Glenn's increasingly sharp political thrusts at   Walter F. Mondale may be prompted by more than the intensifying rivalry between the two Democrats for their party's 1984 Presidential nomination. A new campaign...

byline.original: By James F. Clarity and Warren Weaver Jr

results.lead_paragraph: '76 Glenn Speech Flap Senator John Glenn's increasingly sharp political thrusts at Walter F. Mondale may be prompted by more than the intensifying rivalry between the two Democrats for their party's 1984 Presidential nomination. A new campaign biography suggests that Senator Glenn has blamed Mr. Mondale ever since 1976 for the poor reception given his keynote speech at the national convention in New York City. In ''Glenn, the Astronaut Who Would Be President,'' Frank Van Riper reports that ''some believe that the noise and interruptions'' during the Glenn speech ''were not spontaneous but part of a plan developed by liberal and labor delegates who favored Mondale'' as Jimmy Carter's running mate ''and hoped to deny the No. 2 spot to Glenn.'' During the Glenn speech, Senator Hubert H. Humphrey and Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr. appeared on the convention floor, prompting television interviews that diverted attention from the lectern.

results.snippet: Dinners and Dancing  BY ROBERT E. TOMASSON      Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.        Dutch Award Nov. 2 - The highest spot in Manhattan seems an especially appropriate location to honor...
results.lead_paragraph: Dinners and Dancing BY ROBERT E. TOMASSON Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated. Dutch Award Nov. 2 - The highest spot in Manhattan seems an especially appropriate location to honor an astronaut of Dutch descent, considering the Dutch origins of New York as well as the elevation of the World Trade Center. The astronaut is Jack R. Lousma, a Marine colonel who was the Skylab 2 pilot and commander of the third orbital test flight of the space shuttle Columbia. He has spent 1,619 hours in space, including 11 hours in space walks. The

results.snippet: Australian Crew Honored    PERTH, Australia, Oct. 30 (UPI) - Tens of thousands of people welcomed home today the crew of Australia II, which captured the America's Cup last month in Newport, R.I.   Australia II, representing the Royal Perth Yacht...
results.lead_paragraph: Australian Crew Honored PERTH, Australia, Oct. 30 (UPI) - Tens of thousands of people welcomed home today the crew of Australia II, which captured the America's Cup last month in Newport, R.I. Australia II, representing the Royal Perth Yacht Club, beat Liberty in the final race of a seven-race series to end the New York Yacht Club's 132- year hold on the cup. Alan Bond, head of the Australian syndicate, and his crew were greeted at the port city of Fremantle at a civic reception and were carried in a 30-car motorcade 10 miles to the city of Perth for a parade that ended on the banks of the Swan River.
